content: The Act may be cited as the "Asthma Awareness, Education and Treatment Act of 1999". The Congress finds that asthma affects 14.6 million Americans, including 4.8 million children, and allergies impact 40-50 million Americans. Asthma is the most common chronic respiratory disease in children, causing 25% of school absenteeism and being the third leading cause of preventable hospitalizations. Pediatric asthma prevalence increased by 72% from 1980 to 1994, with a 160% rise in preschool children with asthma. In 1997, over 5,000 Americans died from asthma. Asthma prevalence is higher in women than in men, with a greater impact on low-income families. In 1997, over 5,000 Americans died from asthma. The average number of deaths from asthma for African Americans was 38.5 deaths per million individuals, while for Caucasians it was 15.1 deaths per million. Asthma costs the US over $12 billion annually, with a rising prevalence leading to higher future costs. African Americans are five times more likely than other populations to seek care for asthma. Asthma leads to higher costs in the future, with African Americans being five times more likely to seek care at an emergency room. The asthma death rate is four times higher among African American children and two times higher among all African Americans. Exercise improves children's well-being, self-esteem, and helps manage asthma, forming lifelong habits of physical activity that can improve quality and length of life. SEC. 4. NATIONAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN TO PROVIDE ASTHMA-RELATED INFORMATION. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may award contracts for a national media campaign to provide information on asthma, allergies, and related respiratory problems, with a focus on children. The campaign must include information on prevention and management of these conditions. The campaign provides information on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems, including screenings, referrals, and treatment in the community. It is carried out in the appropriate language and cultural context. The campaign on asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems is conducted in the language and cultural context suitable for the target audience. $600,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for subsequent years. SEC. 5. TAX CREDIT FOR DONATIONS OF PEST CONTROL AND CLIMATE CONTROL SERVICES. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new section for a tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services. For taxpayers providing pest control or climate control services, the donation credit is 10% of the total cost incurred in offering qualified services without charge. The term 'qualified pest control and climate control services' refers to services provided without charge in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties with a majority of occupants having incomes below 200 percent of the poverty line, as part of a good faith effort to address pest and climate control issues. The text discusses the provision of pest control and climate control services in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties for occupants below 200 percent of the poverty line as part of a good faith effort. The services aim to eliminate pests and improve ventilation and temperature control. The provision aims to improve ventilation and temperature control in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties for occupants below 200 percent of the poverty line by providing pest control and climate control services. The taxpayer engaged in providing pest control or climate control services can claim a donation credit under section 45D, with restrictions on carrying back the credit before January 1, 2000. The unused business credit for any taxable year related to the credit under section 45D cannot be carried back before January 1, 2000. The amendments made by section 45D apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. Research on the relationship between air pollutants and asthma-related issues is addressed in section 6. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the EPA Administrator, will conduct research to determine the link between air pollutants and asthma, allergies, and respiratory problems. Priority will be given to clinical research for individuals affected by these issues. The Secretary will prioritize clinical evaluations for individuals in low-income communities for research on the link between air pollutants and respiratory issues. SEC. 7. COORDINATION OF FEDERAL ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS ASTHMA-RELATED HEALTH CARE NEEDS. The Director of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute will identify federal asthma programs, develop a federal response plan, and submit recommendations to Congress for improving coordination of asthma-related activities within 12 months of this Act's enactment. The National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee will submit recommendations to Congress on improving asthma-related activities coordination. A representative from the Department of Housing and Urban Development will be included in the committee. $5,000,000 will be allocated from NIH funds to the program. $5,000,000 allocated to National Asthma Education Prevention Program from NIH funds for fiscal years 2000-2004. SEC. 8. COMPILATION OF DATA BY CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, conducts local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management quality through telephone surveys and health care facility surveillance. They also compile and publish annual data on asthma. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, conducts local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management quality. They also compile and annually publish data on the prevalence of children suffering from asthma in each State and the childhood mortality rate associated with asthma nationally and in each State.
